Award.AwardTitle: Increasing Diversity in the Sciences II

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This S-STEM project at Allegheny College is providing scholarships for fourteen undergraduates in the Natural Sciences for four years. Through its support for the education and training of academically talented, financially needy students, the project is helping to meet local and regional employment needs in research and technical fields, as well as serving as a source of lessons learned for other institutions facing similar challenges.

Several features of the project's implementation stand out. Eligible students are being selected from a pool of high school applicants based on their interest in STEM fields, academic potential, and financial need. Scholarship students receive academic and cohort support, which builds on the College's existing support structure. Academic support includes a co-advising component by which each student has one of the principal investigators as an academic advisor in addition to one of the full-time professional staff from the academic support office serving as a co-advisor. Scholarship recipients are also participating in a one-week academic enrichment program prior to the start of classes. Cohort support is being structured around a Living and Learning Community (LLC), which includes housing on the same floor of a designated residence hall, regular lunches (biweekly during the first year and monthly thereafter) along with presentations from support offices, career services, science faculty and students, and other personnel. Each student is also having regular contact with the Director and the Assistant Director of Allegheny College's diversity office. These individuals also serve as members of the management team along with the two principal investigators, the director of the academic support center, and the director of financial aid.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of Allegheny College's implementation of the S-STEM program was to increase diversity in STEM fields by recruiting academically strong students from under-represented groups and providing academic and cohort support for these students throughout their four years at Allegheny.

In addition to meeting financial need requirements, prospective students had to rank academically in one of the top two tiers of Admissions' five-tier system. Although any student meeting the academic and financial need requirements was eligible we intentionally focused our recruitment on students of color. Students accepting the scholarship agreed to declare a major in a natural science department and to maintain at least a 3.0 GPA in their major.

The funds granted by NSF were used to award $10,000 annual scholarships for two cohorts of students, designated NSF Scholars, for four years. The first cohort matriculated in fall 2014 and the second in fall 2015. Funding from NSF supported seven students per cohort, while the College provided additional scholarships, at the same level, for up to an additional five students per cohort. The College also provided internal grants that enabled all NSF Scholars to graduate without loans. The first cohort consisted of 11 students, seven funded by NSF and the remaining four by the College. The second cohort was comprised of 12 students, with seven students funded by NSF and five by the College.

NSF Scholars received the following academic and cohort support:

- Academic co-advising with each student assigned two advisors, one being one of the PIs and the other the Director of our academic support center, the Learning Commons.

- A pre-orientation program beginning three days prior to matriculation consisting of a combination of academic preparation and cohort-building activities.

- Participation in a Living-Learning Community during their first year with all entering NSF Scholars housed together on the same floor of a first-year residence hall.

- Enrollment in an exclusive First-Year Seminar taught by one of the PIs during the fall semester.

- Regular catered lunches hosted by the PIs and the co-advisor with presentations from our academic support staff, diversity office and career services personnel. Other lunches included faculty from natural science departments to help students explore science majors and receive information regarding summer and academic year research opportunities, both on-campus and off.

- Depending on the need, students were also required to meet regularly with their advisor or co-advisor in order to receive additional academic support.

In addition, students were encouraged, though not required, to seek out summer research and internship opportunities either off-campus through the NSF's Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, through other programs, or on campus with Allegheny faculty. (The College provided stipends and housing for students who engaged in summer research on campus.) They were also encouraged to pursue research with Allegheny faculty as independent studies during the academic year. 

In terms of retention, academic performance, and student satisfaction the S-STEM program has been very successful, especially given the fact that students of color and high financial need tend to have lower overall rates of success in college. Of the original 23 students from the combined cohorts two left the program because they left the college and two left because they switched to non-science majors, for an overall retention rate of 83 percent. Seventeen of the 19 continuing students graduated within four years of matriculation, with the remaining two expected to graduate this academic year, 2019-20. The average overall GPA of our NSF Scholars was 3.21. One NSF Scholar, who achieved a 4.0 GPA during her four years at Allegheny, was named co-valedictorian of her graduating class. Two students graduated Summa Cum Laude (GPA ≥ 3.9) and two graduated Magna Cum Laude (GPA ≥ 3.7). 

The students who have graduated have gone on to graduate school in STEM fields, to technical positions in industry, for further training for health professions, and into educational service organizations such as AmeriCorps.

Our implementation of the S-STEM scholarship program is the only one on our campus focused on students intending to major in the sciences. Based in part on the success of our NSF Scholars program, the College has begun to institute other programs targeted at similar cohorts of students. These new programs are using many of the support features we have implemented for our S-STEM students. Thus our S-STEM grant has not only been an opportunity to produce a new cohort of scientists from a diverse demographic, but also allowed us to gain experience in this type of effort and see it implemented in a sustained way at our institution, and hopefully, to provide a model for similar programs at other institutions.
